December 27, 2018

Young Girl with Her Hair by Pierre-Auguste Renoir [Public domain] Wikipedia Commons

After taking a look in part one at the clues throughout the text that suggest Florian was a young hedge knight, we then took a slight detour with part 2 to discuss his and Jonquil’s symbolic connection to the Capricorn and Pisces signs of the Zodiac via the sigils of House Mooton and Tully.  We also discussed House Mooton and its connection to the real world myth of Enki, the Sumerian god of water, which as in so many other mythical comparisons in the text connect Jon and Sansa via Florian and Jonquil to fertility myths about the renewal of the land.  Now, it’s time to get back to digging into the clues about Jonquil, the individual character—starting with why she was most likely a redhead as I briefly discussed in the last chapter.

Although of symbolic importance, Sansa’s red hair and the fact that House Mooton’s sigil is a red salmon are not the primary reasons for my thinking Jonquil had kissed by fire hair.  George has actually dropped several other strong hints to support this theory in The Hedge Knight and the other Dunk and Egg novellas as well as the recently released Fire & Blood.  Let’s talk first about the former because as I mentioned in part one, Dunk should be viewed as a stand-in for Florian in the story and George has written a series of novellas about his adventures that provide some of the strongest set of clues about Florian and Jonquil—including the latter’s hair color.

There are redheads of both sexes all over The Hedge Knight. In the novella, we also discover for the first time that Dunk, like another character in the books has a thing for redheads.

The wine sellers and sausage makers were doing a brisk trade, and whores walked brazenly among the stalls and pavilions. Some were pretty enough, one red-haired girl in particular. He could not help staring at her breasts, the way they moved under her loose shift as she sauntered past. He thought of the silver in his pouch. I could have her, if I liked. She’d like the clink of my coin well enough, I could take her back to my camp and have her, all night if I wanted. He had never lain with a woman, and for all he knew he might die in his first tilt. Tourneys could be dangerous … but whores could be dangerous too, the old man had warned him of that. She might rob me while I slept, and what would I do then? When the red-haired girl glanced back over her shoulder at him, Dunk shook his head and walked away.

The Hedge Knight

I find this scene with the whore very interesting as I think it might have been the inspiration for Dan and Dave’s creation of Roz on the show.  And like Jon did with Roz, Dunk, rejects the red-haired whore.  

However, like Jon with Ygritte, we later see that Dunk definitely has a thing for redheads when he encounters Rohanne Weber in The Sworn Sword.  We will talk a little bit more about both Rohanne and Ygritte later in the essay but for now, I just want to discuss the similarities in their description to each other as well as to the red-hair whore that Dunk sees.

[[MORE]]

“And what is all this merriment?” The voice cut through the laughter, cool and firm. “Will no one share the jape? Ser knight, why are you troubling my good-sister?”

It was the girl he had seen earlier at the archery butts. She had a quiver of arrows on one hip, and held a longbow that was just as tall as she was, which wasn’t very tall. If Dunk was shy an inch of seven feet, the archer was shy an inch of five. He could have spanned her waist with his two hands. Her red hair was bound up in a braid so long it brushed past her thighs, and she had a dimpled chin, a snub nose, and a light spray of freckles across her cheeks.

“Forgive us, Lady Rohanne.” The speaker was a pretty young lord with the Caswell centaur embroidered on his doublet. “This great oaf took the Lady Helicent for you.”

The Sworn Sword

And here are a couple of descriptions of Ygritte.  Make note of the similarities between the three and keep in mind that like Lady Rohanne, Ygritte was also an archer.

Ygritte watched and said nothing. She was older than he’d thought at first, Jon realized; maybe as old as twenty, but short for her age, bandy-legged, with a round face, small hands, and a pug nose. Her shaggy mop of red hair stuck out in all directions. She looked plump as she crouched there, but most of that was layers of fur and wool and leather. Underneath all that she could be as skinny as Arya.

A Clash of Kings - Jon VI

“We should.” Her breasts bounced as she stood on one leg to pull one boot, then hopped onto her other foot to attend to the other. Her nipples were wide pink circles. “You as well,” Ygritte said as she yanked down her sheepskin breeches. “If you want to look you have to show. You know nothing, Jon Snow.”

A Storm of Swords - Jon III

All three women are of course redheads.  I’m not sure of the importance of the bouncy breasts…maybe just George remembering someone in his personal life.  Who knows!  Ygritte and the redhead whore are the ones described as having bouncy breast—not Rohanne.  In fact, as we see from this Dunk dream sequence, Rohanne’s breasts were most likely pretty small.

Drowsing at long last, Dunk dreamed. He was running through a glade in the heart of Wat’s Wood, running toward Rohanne, and she was shooting arrows at him. Each shaft she loosed flew true, and pierced him through the chest, yet the pain was strangely sweet. He should have turned and fled, but he ran toward her instead, running slowly as you always did in dreams, as if the very air had turned to honey. Another arrow came, and yet another. Her quiver seemed to have no end of shafts. Her eyes were gray and green and full of mischief. Your gown brings out the color of your eyes, he meant to say to her, but she was not wearing any gown, or any clothes at all. Across her small breasts was a faint spray of freckles, and her nipples were red and hard as little berries. The arrows made him look like some great porcupine as he went stumbling to her feet, but somehow he still found the strength to grab her braid.

With one hard yank he pulled her down on top of him and kissed her.

He woke suddenly, at the sound of a shout.

The Sworn Sword

Rohanne and Ygritte are also described as short and while the height of the whore walking through the crowds is not given, it is not a ridiculous assumption to assume that she was as well.  Dunk was almost 7 feet and so he would have no problem seeing a shorter person in a crowd.  I think the most important things to note about them are their height, red hair, freckles on their faces and archery skills of two of the three.

There is another redhead in the books whose description is intriguingly similar to these three women.  And like the redhead Dunk saw at the Tourney of Ashford Meadows, she is also a whore.

"Is milord feeling unloved?” Dancy slid into his lap and nibbled at his ear. “I have a cure for that.”

Smiling, Tyrion shook his head. “You are too beautiful for words, sweetling, but I’ve grown fond of Alayaya’s remedy.”

“You’ve never tried mine. Milord never chooses anyone but ‘Yaya. She’s good but I’m better, don’t you want to see?”

“Next time, perhaps.” Tyrion had no doubt that Dancy would be a lively handful. She was pug-nosed and bouncy, with freckles and a mane of thick red hair that tumbled down past her waist. But he had Shae waiting for him at the manse.

A Clash of Kings - Tyrion VII

Dancy’s height is not given but based on how she is described as sitting on Tyrion’s lap, one can probably deduce that she is not too tall or else Tyrion’s mental thoughts would have filled us in.  Again we get the bouncy reference but I am not even going to attempt to analyze GRRM’s psyche or why he describes the whores and Ygritte, a Wilding girl in this manner but Lady Rohanne as having the more refined small breast.

There is also another redheaded whore that I want to point out.  This one appears in the scene when Arya hears the summoning bells that lead her to seeing her father beheaded.  While George does not use the word bouncy, you can see from the description of her breast that he is following the same theme.

“The bells again, gods ha'mercy,” wailed an old woman.

A red-haired whore in a wisp of painted silk pushed open a second-story window. “Is it the boy king that’s died now?” she shouted down, leaning out over the street. “Ah, that’s a boy for you, they never last long.” As she laughed, a naked man slid his arms around her from behind, biting her neck and rubbing the heavy white breasts that hung loose beneath her shift.

“Stupid slut,” the fat man shouted up. “The king’s not dead, that’s only summoning bells. One tower tolling. When the king dies, they ring every bell in the city.”

A Game of Thrones - Arya V

George wants us to think of Dunk as the symbolic Florian.  He even goes so far to have him and Tanselle role play a scene from the song of Florian and Jonquil to push the point home.  Dunk also plays Florian in his travels throughout the land as a hedge knight and so we must look to the women he encounters for clues of Jonquil.

“You must think me an utter fool.”

She smiled. “All men are fools, and all men are knights.”

“What color paint do you have?” he asked, hoping that might give him an idea.

The Hedge Knight

If we take the descriptions of Lady Rohanne and the whore in the crowd as clues to Jonquil then we also need to look at the various redheads throughout the books to see whether we can find more clues representative of Jonquil.  We can see from the descriptions of the redheads that I’ve mentioned that she was most likely also short with freckles.  Then of course there is the implication that she was a prostitute.  

Except for the fact that she is a redhead, on first reading, none of these descriptions fit Sansa, the symbolic Jonquil in the story proper.  She is not short, does not have freckles and is of course not a whore.  However, she is connected to the world of prostitution via the fact that Petyr, the “father” of her Alayne persona is a brothel owner who turned her best friend Jeyne into a whore before selling her to the Boltons as an Arya stand-in.  And as I will show a little later, the theme of shortness and freckles come into play in her story as well.

Now the fact that both Dunk and Jon have a thing for redheads and that several appear in their story arcs does not mean Jonquil was one as well.  In point of fact, a big part of my theory about her being a redhead has to do with Maidenpool and Duskendale.

The whore is not the only encounter Dunk has with a redhead at the Tourney of Ashford Meadows.  The other encounters are with males—Ser Donnel, a knight of the King’s Guard and Ser Manfred of House Dondarrion who like his descendent, Beric also has red gold hair.  And these individuals also point at the likelihood that Jonquil was a redhead.  This is especially true of Ser Donnel.

By the time Dunk left the stable, Lord Ashford had escorted his princely guests into the hail, but two of the Kingsguard knights in their white armor and snowy cloaks still lingered in the yard, talking with the captain of the guard. Dunk halted before them. “M'lords, I am Ser Duncan the Tall.”

“Well met, Ser Duncan,” answered the bigger of the white knights. “I am Ser Roland Crakehall, and this is my Sworn Brother, Ser Donnel of Duskendale.”

The seven champions of the Kingsguard were the most puissant warriors in all the Seven Kingdoms, saving only perhaps the crown prince, Baelor Breakspear himself. “Have you come to enter the lists?” Dunk asked anxiously.

“It would not be fitting for us to ride against those we are sworn to protect,” answered Ser Donnel, red of hair and beard.

The Hedge Knight

As I’ve been working under the theory that Jonquil was a redhead, I found Ser Donnel’s red hair to be an interesting detail because he is from Duskendale and as I mentioned above, it borders Maidenpool.  Something told me that point was important but there was no other detail given about him and his House was not mentioned in The Hedge Knight and so I had to leave it alone.  That is until we first became aware of Jonquil Darke, the sworn shield of Good Queen Alysanne as revealed in the excerpt of Fire & Blood George posted on his website in advance of the book’s release.

Lord Manderly entertained the queen lavishly. At the welcoming feast an entire aurochs was roasted, and his lordship’s daughter Jessamyn acted as the queen’s cupbearer, filling her tankard with a strong northern ale that Her Grace pronounced finer than any wine she had ever tasted. Manderly also staged a small tourney in the queen’s honor, to show the prowess of his knights. One of the fighters (though no knight) was revealed to be a woman, a wildling girl who had been captured by rangers north of the Wall and given to one of Lord Manderly’s household knights to foster. Delighted by the girl’s daring, Alysanne summoned her own sworn shield, Jonquil Darke, and the wildling and the Scarlet Shadow dueled spear against sword whilst the northmen roared in approval.

Fire & Blood: Jaehaerys and Alysanne - Their Triumphs and Tragedies

Jonquil Darke also had something in common with Sansa Stark in that she was a bastard daughter.  In the case of the Scarlet Shadow, her father was the Lord of Duskendale.  Sansa is of course only pretending while Jonquil Darke was a true bastard but it is interesting that both are associated with the word.  Does this mean that the original Jonquil was also a bastard?  Yes, but not quite in the way you may think, as we will soon discover.

There is a ton of symbolism associated with the name of Jonquil Darke, which I will be discussing when I get to the section dedicated specifically to the character.  For now, let’s discuss how and why she came by her Scarlet Shadow sobriquet.  

The shadow part of her moniker is because once she became Alysanne’s personal guard, she never left her side.  When you saw the queen, Jonquil was always a step behind her.  She became Alysanne’s figurative shadow.

A raven flew to Duskendale that very night, commanding the new Lord Darklyn to send to court his bastard half-sister, Jonquil Darke, who had thrilled the smallfolk during the War for the White Cloaks as the mystery knight known as the Serpent in Scarlet. Still in scarlet, she arrived at King’s Landing a few days later, and gladly accepted appointment as the queen’s own sworn shield. In time, she would be known about the realm as the Scarlet Shadow, so closely did she guard her lady.

Fire and Blood: Birth, Death and Betrayal under King Jaehaerys 1

The scarlet sobriquet was because she always dressed in red.  Was this because red was the color of her House sigil? Quite possible!  Might she have had red hair as well?  This is also possible, as redheads seem to be very common in the Maidenpool/Duskendale area.  

Red hair is a result of a recessive gene that occurs in only about 2% of the world’s population.  I know that we are dealing with a fantasy series but still in all, even with all the fantastical elements, George tends to stay within scientific norms.  For this reason, I would argue that the number of redheads referenced in the books from the Duskendale/Maidenpool area are numerically out of the statistical mean and like with the ones in attendance at the Tourney of Ashford Meadows, it is meant to draw attention to Jonquil.

We can deduce from the legend of Florian the Brave, which I mentioned in part 1 of this series that on a Doylist level, Martin named the family members of the area houses after the famous original pair.  This makes sense on a Watsonian level as well since the Lords and Ladies of the said houses would also be inclined to name their progeny after such a storied pair.  

House Darke is a cadet branch of House Darklyn, which gives it a connection to the Duskendale/Maidenpool area.  This could explain why the Scarlet Shadow was given the name of Jonquil.  It also suggests that George wants the reader to associate and compare her and her background with the original Jonquil and so that is just what we will do.

She is known as the Scarlet Shadow and this moniker gave me my connection to Ser Donnel who is from the Duskendale area and whom I now propose was also a member of House Darklyn.  And while this does not have to be the case, one can’t help but presupposed that the scarlet in her moniker is also in reference to her hair and she like Ser Donnel was a redhead.  

Not much is know about other members of House Darke or Darklyn except that they supported the blacks during the Dance with Dragons and that several sons were members of the Kings and Queens guard.  This included 7 sons of House Darklyn who were Kingsguard members and one Ser Harrold of House Darke who was a member of the Queen Rhaenrya’s guard during the Dance of Dragons.  And we now know that a Jonquil Darke was a member of Queen Alysanne’s guard.  It is interesting that the Darklyns protected the kings while the Darkes seem to have done the same for the queens.  There is probably a story there and maybe we will find out when The Winds of Winter is released.

The other interesting story about House Darklyn is of the Defiance of Duskendale which led to the then Lord of the House kidnapping King Aerys and his imprisoning him in a dark dungeon for half a year, which no doubt contributed to his already growing madness.  After Ser Barristan Selmy rescued him, Aerys had all members of House Darklyn and almost all of those from House Hollard, who supported the defiance killed.  The only family member of either house to survive was a young son of House Hollard.  Ser Barristan begged for his life and because Aerys owed him a debt for rescuing him from the dungeon, he granted the boon.  

Ser Barristan took the boy back to Kings Landing with him as his squire.  This lad was of course Dontos Hollard who grew up to be Sansa Stark’s symbolic Florian.  A sad and poor version of the legendary knight was Dontos.   He was only in it for the money but he did help her escape from Kings Landing and did teach her some valuable lessons about the game of thrones.  With Dontos, Sansa’s pretend Florian being from Duskendale; we see again how heavily her arc is tied up with the past events from that area as well as Maidenpool region.

The color of Dontos hair is never given in the text but an interesting detail about him that is not often mentioned is that he is also called “Dontos the Red.”  Why he has this moniker is never stated.  It may have something to do with his alcoholism and him possibly always being red of face.  However, with the preponderance of redheads from the Duskendale area, more than likely the moniker pertains to his hair color.  This is especially true as Dontos; the Red makes one immediately think of the famous Viking, Erik, the Red who was so named because of his red hair and beard.

Kiss by fire redheads are part of a very important and mysterious theme in the books.  If Dontos is a redhead as I speculate, then here we have another scarlet hair individual from Duskendale.  This is quite a lot of references to redheaded individuals from an area that ostensibly have nothing to do with the central story.  And yet, the tale of Duskendale and past events that happened there are referenced in all the books except for A Game of Thrones.  This includes the ancillary Dunk and Egg novellas.  Why?  

Why does it play such a major role in the arc of Sansa Stark?  She has actually never visited Duskendale as she went directly to the Vale after escaping from Kings Landing.  However, if she had traveled by land, she most likely would have travel through Duskendale on the way to the Vale.  But that was not her escape route.  Instead, she went by ship and so sailed directly to the Fingers.  Nonetheless, she is still strongly associated with the area as Dontos is from the region and it is where Brienne went in search of him and the missing Sansa.

Florian of course first saw Jonquil at Maidenpool, which as I’ve previously noted, borders Duskendale.  @RoseOfRedLake has a wonderful essay about the importance of Maidenpool and the role it has played in the story so far and potentially may in the future.   Maybe it’s because Duskendale neighbors Maidenpool that it is featured so prominently in the books.  That could be part of the reason but maybe there is more to it.

I wondered earlier whether Jonquil was from Maidenpool or if she was just visiting the pool on her way to another location.  As luck would have it, George has provided several hints in Fire and Blood that it may be the second option.

While on a royal progress with Jaehaerys, Alysanne decided to visit Jonquil’s healing pool for a bath.  One interesting aspect of her visit is the fact prior to arriving in Maidenpool the couple visited Duskendale.

They began with Stokeworth and Rosby, then moved north along the coast to Duskendale.  There, whilst the king viewed Lord Darklyn’s boatyards and enjoyed an afternoon of fishing, the queen held the first of her women’s courts, which were to become an important part of every royal progress to come. Only women and girls were welcome at these audiences; highborn or low, they were encouraged to come forward and share their fears, concerns, and hopes with the young queen.

The journey went without incident until the king and queen reached Maidenpool, where they were to be the guests of Lord and Lady Mooton for a fortnight before sailing across the Bay of Crabs to Wickenden, Gulltown, and the Vale.

Fire and Blood: Birth, Death and Betrayal under King Jaehaerys 1

Before arriving in Maidenpool, the royal progress may have stopped at Antlers or Rook’s Rest.  However, they could have travel directly from Duskendale to Maidenpool without a stop in-between.  As they were traveling along the coast, it would have been more likely that they stopped at Rook’s Rest as opposed to Antlers but as it was a progress, they most likely stopped in both areas.  

However, unlike with the mention of Stokeworth and Rosby, George makes no mention of these other two towns.  The text goes straight from Jaehaerys and Alysanne being in Duskendale to them in Maidenpool.  It’s almost as if George wants you to associate the two towns with each other.  This is something he does on numerous occasions throughout the various books as the towns are often grouped together…almost as a unit.  

I proposed that the reason for this is because Jonquil in point of fact was not from Maidenpool as many assume.  Maidenpool is the location of the famous pool where Florian first saw Jonquil but nowhere does it say that it was the location of her birth.  Instead, I believe Florian first saw her there simply because like Alysanne, her and her party stop there to rest and refresh themselves in the local pool.  I think that it’s possible that she was either from Duskendale or had family who resided there that she was visiting.  

As Jonquil was familiar with Florian’s name, he might have been from the region as well.  And I think that this could be why Duskendale and Maidenpool are always linked in the text.

This morning the puppeteers were doing the tale of Florian and Jonquil. The fat Dornishwoman was working Florian in his armor made of motley, while the tall girl held Jonquil’s strings. “You are no knight,” she was saying as the puppet’s mouth moved up and down. “I know you. You are Florian the Fool.”

“I am, my lady,” the other puppet answered, kneeling. “As great a fool as ever lived, and as great a knight as well.”

The Hedge Knight

I mentioned that Jonquil might possibly have been from Duskendale or had family in the region.  However, there is one other area from which she might have been born. There are many hints in Fire & Blood that suggest that Alysanne’s story offer clues to that of Sansa.  And I think that one of the ways it does this is with the story of Florian and Jonquil.  

Jaehaerys and Alysanne arrived in Maidenpool from Duskendale only for the queen to be attacked when she visited Jonquil’s pool.

The goodness of the little queen, the silence of the Starry Sept, and the exhortations of the Seven Speakers had won over most of the Faithful for Jaehaerys and his Alysanne…but there are always some who will not be moved, and amongst the sisters who tended Jonquil’s Pool were three such women, whose hearts were hard with hate. They told one another that their holy waters would be polluted forever were the queen allowed to bathe in them whilst carrying the king’s “abomination” in her belly. Queen Alysanne had only slipped out of her clothing when they fell upon her with daggers they had concealed within their robes.

Fire and Blood: Birth, Death and Betrayal Under King Jaehaerys I

Her ladies-in-waiting foiled the attempt on Alysanne and the two Kings Guards assigned to her.  However, it also forced her and Jaehaerys to end their progress and return to Kings Landing.

A raven flew to Duskendale that very night, commanding the new Lord Darklyn to send to court his bastard half-sister, Jonquil Darke, who had thrilled the smallfolk during the War for the White Cloaks as the mystery knight known as the Serpent in Scarlet. Still in scarlet, she arrived at King’s Landing a few days later, and gladly accepted appointment as the queen’s own sworn shield. In time, she would be known about the realm as the Scarlet Shadow, so closely did she guard her lady.

Fire and Blood: Birth, Death and Betrayal Under King Jaehaerys I

So we have Alysanne who Martin has written to parallel Sansa in so many ways arriving at Maidenpool from Duskendale.  Then after visiting Jonquil’s pool where she is attacked, she sends to Duskendale for her own personal female guard.  One that just happens to be named Jonquil and quite possibly may have been a redhead

Also, let’s not forget that Brienne goes searching for Sansa, the in-story symbolic stand-in for Jonquil in Duskendale.  When she has no luck there she heads over to Maidenpool where Lord Tarly is now in control.

"If the Stark girl were here, I’d know it. She’s run back north, I’ll wager. Hoping to find refuge with one of her father’s bannermen. She had best hope she chooses the right one.”

“She might have gone to the Vale instead,” Brienne heard herself blurt out, “to her mother’s sister.”

Lord Randyll gave her a contemptuous look. “Lady Lysa is dead. Some singer pushed her off a mountain. Littlefinger holds the Eyrie now … though not for long. The lords of the Vale are not the sort to bend their knees to some upjumped jackanapes whose only skill is counting coppers.”

A Feast for Crows - Brienne III

Brienne should have trusted her instincts because Sansa is of course in the Vale.  The interesting thing about the Vale is that it was the planned final destination of the royal progress and it was the next stop after Maidenpool.  The attack on Alysanne’s forced the King and Queen returned to Kings Landing, making plans to visit the Vale at a future date.  As I mentioned previously, if Sansa had travelled to the Vale overland instead of via water, she would have followed the same path as Alysanne and Jaehaerys.

With all these symbolic Jonquils connected to or traveling from Duskendale to Maidenpool to the Vale, is it possible that the original followed the same path?  Is it possible that she was from Duskendale and she only stopped in Maidenpool on the way to her final destination in the Vale?  Or is the reverse true and she was traveling from the Vale to Duskendale and only stopped in Maidenpool to rest.  With Sansa’s symbolic connection to all three areas, I believe that one of these options is true and it is what George wants us to consider.  And if we can figure out which one is correct, we may be one step closer to answering the great mystery of the series.

We have reviewed the many clues that suggest that Jonquil was a “kissed by fire” redhead and briefly looked at hints that she was also short in stature.  All of the females that I mentioned who tip to Jonquil having red hair were described as short or at least it was intimated that they were.  Let’s now look at one other scene with Dunk, the Florian that supports my thesis that she was short.  It’s a memory that occurs to Dunk just after he speaks to Tanselle, the Jonquil surrogate for the first time.

“Will you drink a horn of ale?” he asked the puppet girl as she was scooping the sawdust blood back into her dragon. “With me, I mean? Or a sausage? I had a sausage last night, and it was good. They’re made with pork, I think.”

“I thank you, m'lord, but we have another show.” The girl rose, and ran off to the fierce fat Dornishwoman who worked the puppet knight while Dunk stood there feeling stupid. He liked the way she ran, though. A pretty girl, and tall. I would not have to kneel to kiss that one. He knew how to kiss.

A tavern girl had showed him one night in Lannisport, a year ago, but she’d been so short she had to sit on the table to reach his lips. The memory made his ears burn. What a great fool he was. It was jousting he should be thinking about, not kissing.

The Hedge Knight

Why did Martin make the girl of Dunk’s memory so short in height if it was not to hint at something?  As the memory of her comes to him just after he has seen the puppet show about Florian and Jonquil and his brief conversation with Tanselle, it’s quite possible that it’s a clue to Jonquil’s height.  At the same time, Martin also has Dunk mentally call himself a fool so that we the reader can link him to Florian and a short female.  

The fact that George keeps hinting at her being short in stature must mean that it is of some importance to the story.  I think that Jonquil’s height is in fact of extreme consequence, as we will discover a bit later in the essay series.

One final point I want to mention about Dunk’s brief conversation with Tanselle is his invitation for her to go and have a horn of ale and a pork sausage with him.  Dunk is an innocent but we the readers know that horns and sausages…especially the pork kind comes with all sorts of sexual innuendos.  And so we see again how the fertility theme is constantly running through the Florian and Jonquil arc.  

This brings us to the end of part 3.  In the next chapter, sausages come into play again as we look at a curious textural error in The Hedge Knight and ponder whether it was a mistake or if it was a deliberate on Martin’s part.  And we also take a look at Mary Magdalene because if they are suggestions of a symbolic Christ in the story one would expect some hints of Mary Magdalene as well. It turns out that there quite possibly are such clues and in a most surprising way.

You may read the other chapters of this essay at the following links.

Part 2

Part 4

Part 5

trail.content_raw:
December 27, 2018

Young Girl with Her Hair by Pierre-Auguste Renoir [Public domain] Wikipedia Commons

After taking a look in part one at the clues throughout the text that suggest Florian was a young hedge knight, we then took a slight detour with part 2 to discuss his and Jonquil’s symbolic connection to the Capricorn and Pisces signs of the Zodiac via the sigils of House Mooton and Tully.  We also discussed House Mooton and its connection to the real world myth of Enki, the Sumerian god of water, which as in so many other mythical comparisons in the text connect Jon and Sansa via Florian and Jonquil to fertility myths about the renewal of the land.  Now, it’s time to get back to digging into the clues about Jonquil, the individual character—starting with why she was most likely a redhead as I briefly discussed in the last chapter.

Although of symbolic importance, Sansa’s red hair and the fact that House Mooton’s sigil is a red salmon are not the primary reasons for my thinking Jonquil had kissed by fire hair.  George has actually dropped several other strong hints to support this theory in The Hedge Knight and the other Dunk and Egg novellas as well as the recently released Fire & Blood.  Let’s talk first about the former because as I mentioned in part one, Dunk should be viewed as a stand-in for Florian in the story and George has written a series of novellas about his adventures that provide some of the strongest set of clues about Florian and Jonquil—including the latter’s hair color.

There are redheads of both sexes all over The Hedge Knight. In the novella, we also discover for the first time that Dunk, like another character in the books has a thing for redheads.

The wine sellers and sausage makers were doing a brisk trade, and whores walked brazenly among the stalls and pavilions. Some were pretty enough, one red-haired girl in particular. He could not help staring at her breasts, the way they moved under her loose shift as she sauntered past. He thought of the silver in his pouch. I could have her, if I liked. She’d like the clink of my coin well enough, I could take her back to my camp and have her, all night if I wanted. He had never lain with a woman, and for all he knew he might die in his first tilt. Tourneys could be dangerous … but whores could be dangerous too, the old man had warned him of that. She might rob me while I slept, and what would I do then? When the red-haired girl glanced back over her shoulder at him, Dunk shook his head and walked away.

The Hedge Knight

I find this scene with the whore very interesting as I think it might have been the inspiration for Dan and Dave’s creation of Roz on the show.  And like Jon did with Roz, Dunk, rejects the red-haired whore.  

However, like Jon with Ygritte, we later see that Dunk definitely has a thing for redheads when he encounters Rohanne Weber in The Sworn Sword.  We will talk a little bit more about both Rohanne and Ygritte later in the essay but for now, I just want to discuss the similarities in their description to each other as well as to the red-hair whore that Dunk sees.

[[MORE]]

“And what is all this merriment?” The voice cut through the laughter, cool and firm. “Will no one share the jape? Ser knight, why are you troubling my good-sister?”

It was the girl he had seen earlier at the archery butts. She had a quiver of arrows on one hip, and held a longbow that was just as tall as she was, which wasn’t very tall. If Dunk was shy an inch of seven feet, the archer was shy an inch of five. He could have spanned her waist with his two hands. Her red hair was bound up in a braid so long it brushed past her thighs, and she had a dimpled chin, a snub nose, and a light spray of freckles across her cheeks.

“Forgive us, Lady Rohanne.” The speaker was a pretty young lord with the Caswell centaur embroidered on his doublet. “This great oaf took the Lady Helicent for you.”

The Sworn Sword

And here are a couple of descriptions of Ygritte.  Make note of the similarities between the three and keep in mind that like Lady Rohanne, Ygritte was also an archer.

Ygritte watched and said nothing. She was older than he’d thought at first, Jon realized; maybe as old as twenty, but short for her age, bandy-legged, with a round face, small hands, and a pug nose. Her shaggy mop of red hair stuck out in all directions. She looked plump as she crouched there, but most of that was layers of fur and wool and leather. Underneath all that she could be as skinny as Arya.

A Clash of Kings - Jon VI

“We should.” Her breasts bounced as she stood on one leg to pull one boot, then hopped onto her other foot to attend to the other. Her nipples were wide pink circles. “You as well,” Ygritte said as she yanked down her sheepskin breeches. “If you want to look you have to show. You know nothing, Jon Snow.”

A Storm of Swords - Jon III

All three women are of course redheads.  I’m not sure of the importance of the bouncy breasts…maybe just George remembering someone in his personal life.  Who knows!  Ygritte and the redhead whore are the ones described as having bouncy breast—not Rohanne.  In fact, as we see from this Dunk dream sequence, Rohanne’s breasts were most likely pretty small.

Drowsing at long last, Dunk dreamed. He was running through a glade in the heart of Wat’s Wood, running toward Rohanne, and she was shooting arrows at him. Each shaft she loosed flew true, and pierced him through the chest, yet the pain was strangely sweet. He should have turned and fled, but he ran toward her instead, running slowly as you always did in dreams, as if the very air had turned to honey. Another arrow came, and yet another. Her quiver seemed to have no end of shafts. Her eyes were gray and green and full of mischief. Your gown brings out the color of your eyes, he meant to say to her, but she was not wearing any gown, or any clothes at all. Across her small breasts was a faint spray of freckles, and her nipples were red and hard as little berries. The arrows made him look like some great porcupine as he went stumbling to her feet, but somehow he still found the strength to grab her braid.

With one hard yank he pulled her down on top of him and kissed her.

He woke suddenly, at the sound of a shout.

The Sworn Sword

Rohanne and Ygritte are also described as short and while the height of the whore walking through the crowds is not given, it is not a ridiculous assumption to assume that she was as well.  Dunk was almost 7 feet and so he would have no problem seeing a shorter person in a crowd.  I think the most important things to note about them are their height, red hair, freckles on their faces and archery skills of two of the three.

There is another redhead in the books whose description is intriguingly similar to these three women.  And like the redhead Dunk saw at the Tourney of Ashford Meadows, she is also a whore.

"Is milord feeling unloved?” Dancy slid into his lap and nibbled at his ear. “I have a cure for that.”

Smiling, Tyrion shook his head. “You are too beautiful for words, sweetling, but I’ve grown fond of Alayaya’s remedy.”

“You’ve never tried mine. Milord never chooses anyone but ‘Yaya. She’s good but I’m better, don’t you want to see?”

“Next time, perhaps.” Tyrion had no doubt that Dancy would be a lively handful. She was pug-nosed and bouncy, with freckles and a mane of thick red hair that tumbled down past her waist. But he had Shae waiting for him at the manse.

A Clash of Kings - Tyrion VII

Dancy’s height is not given but based on how she is described as sitting on Tyrion’s lap, one can probably deduce that she is not too tall or else Tyrion’s mental thoughts would have filled us in.  Again we get the bouncy reference but I am not even going to attempt to analyze GRRM’s psyche or why he describes the whores and Ygritte, a Wilding girl in this manner but Lady Rohanne as having the more refined small breast.

There is also another redheaded whore that I want to point out.  This one appears in the scene when Arya hears the summoning bells that lead her to seeing her father beheaded.  While George does not use the word bouncy, you can see from the description of her breast that he is following the same theme.

“The bells again, gods ha'mercy,” wailed an old woman.

A red-haired whore in a wisp of painted silk pushed open a second-story window. “Is it the boy king that’s died now?” she shouted down, leaning out over the street. “Ah, that’s a boy for you, they never last long.” As she laughed, a naked man slid his arms around her from behind, biting her neck and rubbing the heavy white breasts that hung loose beneath her shift.

“Stupid slut,” the fat man shouted up. “The king’s not dead, that’s only summoning bells. One tower tolling. When the king dies, they ring every bell in the city.”

A Game of Thrones - Arya V

George wants us to think of Dunk as the symbolic Florian.  He even goes so far to have him and Tanselle role play a scene from the song of Florian and Jonquil to push the point home.  Dunk also plays Florian in his travels throughout the land as a hedge knight and so we must look to the women he encounters for clues of Jonquil.

“You must think me an utter fool.”

She smiled. “All men are fools, and all men are knights.”

“What color paint do you have?” he asked, hoping that might give him an idea.

The Hedge Knight

If we take the descriptions of Lady Rohanne and the whore in the crowd as clues to Jonquil then we also need to look at the various redheads throughout the books to see whether we can find more clues representative of Jonquil.  We can see from the descriptions of the redheads that I’ve mentioned that she was most likely also short with freckles.  Then of course there is the implication that she was a prostitute.  

Except for the fact that she is a redhead, on first reading, none of these descriptions fit Sansa, the symbolic Jonquil in the story proper.  She is not short, does not have freckles and is of course not a whore.  However, she is connected to the world of prostitution via the fact that Petyr, the “father” of her Alayne persona is a brothel owner who turned her best friend Jeyne into a whore before selling her to the Boltons as an Arya stand-in.  And as I will show a little later, the theme of shortness and freckles come into play in her story as well.

Now the fact that both Dunk and Jon have a thing for redheads and that several appear in their story arcs does not mean Jonquil was one as well.  In point of fact, a big part of my theory about her being a redhead has to do with Maidenpool and Duskendale.

The whore is not the only encounter Dunk has with a redhead at the Tourney of Ashford Meadows.  The other encounters are with males—Ser Donnel, a knight of the King’s Guard and Ser Manfred of House Dondarrion who like his descendent, Beric also has red gold hair.  And these individuals also point at the likelihood that Jonquil was a redhead.  This is especially true of Ser Donnel.

By the time Dunk left the stable, Lord Ashford had escorted his princely guests into the hail, but two of the Kingsguard knights in their white armor and snowy cloaks still lingered in the yard, talking with the captain of the guard. Dunk halted before them. “M'lords, I am Ser Duncan the Tall.”

“Well met, Ser Duncan,” answered the bigger of the white knights. “I am Ser Roland Crakehall, and this is my Sworn Brother, Ser Donnel of Duskendale.”

The seven champions of the Kingsguard were the most puissant warriors in all the Seven Kingdoms, saving only perhaps the crown prince, Baelor Breakspear himself. “Have you come to enter the lists?” Dunk asked anxiously.

“It would not be fitting for us to ride against those we are sworn to protect,” answered Ser Donnel, red of hair and beard.

The Hedge Knight

As I’ve been working under the theory that Jonquil was a redhead, I found Ser Donnel’s red hair to be an interesting detail because he is from Duskendale and as I mentioned above, it borders Maidenpool.  Something told me that point was important but there was no other detail given about him and his House was not mentioned in The Hedge Knight and so I had to leave it alone.  That is until we first became aware of Jonquil Darke, the sworn shield of Good Queen Alysanne as revealed in the excerpt of Fire & Blood George posted on his website in advance of the book’s release.

Lord Manderly entertained the queen lavishly. At the welcoming feast an entire aurochs was roasted, and his lordship’s daughter Jessamyn acted as the queen’s cupbearer, filling her tankard with a strong northern ale that Her Grace pronounced finer than any wine she had ever tasted. Manderly also staged a small tourney in the queen’s honor, to show the prowess of his knights. One of the fighters (though no knight) was revealed to be a woman, a wildling girl who had been captured by rangers north of the Wall and given to one of Lord Manderly’s household knights to foster. Delighted by the girl’s daring, Alysanne summoned her own sworn shield, Jonquil Darke, and the wildling and the Scarlet Shadow dueled spear against sword whilst the northmen roared in approval.

Fire & Blood: Jaehaerys and Alysanne - Their Triumphs and Tragedies

Jonquil Darke also had something in common with Sansa Stark in that she was a bastard daughter.  In the case of the Scarlet Shadow, her father was the Lord of Duskendale.  Sansa is of course only pretending while Jonquil Darke was a true bastard but it is interesting that both are associated with the word.  Does this mean that the original Jonquil was also a bastard?  Yes, but not quite in the way you may think, as we will soon discover.

There is a ton of symbolism associated with the name of Jonquil Darke, which I will be discussing when I get to the section dedicated specifically to the character.  For now, let’s discuss how and why she came by her Scarlet Shadow sobriquet.  

The shadow part of her moniker is because once she became Alysanne’s personal guard, she never left her side.  When you saw the queen, Jonquil was always a step behind her.  She became Alysanne’s figurative shadow.

A raven flew to Duskendale that very night, commanding the new Lord Darklyn to send to court his bastard half-sister, Jonquil Darke, who had thrilled the smallfolk during the War for the White Cloaks as the mystery knight known as the Serpent in Scarlet. Still in scarlet, she arrived at King’s Landing a few days later, and gladly accepted appointment as the queen’s own sworn shield. In time, she would be known about the realm as the Scarlet Shadow, so closely did she guard her lady.

Fire and Blood: Birth, Death and Betrayal under King Jaehaerys 1

The scarlet sobriquet was because she always dressed in red.  Was this because red was the color of her House sigil? Quite possible!  Might she have had red hair as well?  This is also possible, as redheads seem to be very common in the Maidenpool/Duskendale area.  

Red hair is a result of a recessive gene that occurs in only about 2% of the world’s population.  I know that we are dealing with a fantasy series but still in all, even with all the fantastical elements, George tends to stay within scientific norms.  For this reason, I would argue that the number of redheads referenced in the books from the Duskendale/Maidenpool area are numerically out of the statistical mean and like with the ones in attendance at the Tourney of Ashford Meadows, it is meant to draw attention to Jonquil.

We can deduce from the legend of Florian the Brave, which I mentioned in part 1 of this series that on a Doylist level, Martin named the family members of the area houses after the famous original pair.  This makes sense on a Watsonian level as well since the Lords and Ladies of the said houses would also be inclined to name their progeny after such a storied pair.  

House Darke is a cadet branch of House Darklyn, which gives it a connection to the Duskendale/Maidenpool area.  This could explain why the Scarlet Shadow was given the name of Jonquil.  It also suggests that George wants the reader to associate and compare her and her background with the original Jonquil and so that is just what we will do.

She is known as the Scarlet Shadow and this moniker gave me my connection to Ser Donnel who is from the Duskendale area and whom I now propose was also a member of House Darklyn.  And while this does not have to be the case, one can’t help but presupposed that the scarlet in her moniker is also in reference to her hair and she like Ser Donnel was a redhead.  

Not much is know about other members of House Darke or Darklyn except that they supported the blacks during the Dance with Dragons and that several sons were members of the Kings and Queens guard.  This included 7 sons of House Darklyn who were Kingsguard members and one Ser Harrold of House Darke who was a member of the Queen Rhaenrya’s guard during the Dance of Dragons.  And we now know that a Jonquil Darke was a member of Queen Alysanne’s guard.  It is interesting that the Darklyns protected the kings while the Darkes seem to have done the same for the queens.  There is probably a story there and maybe we will find out when The Winds of Winter is released.

The other interesting story about House Darklyn is of the Defiance of Duskendale which led to the then Lord of the House kidnapping King Aerys and his imprisoning him in a dark dungeon for half a year, which no doubt contributed to his already growing madness.  After Ser Barristan Selmy rescued him, Aerys had all members of House Darklyn and almost all of those from House Hollard, who supported the defiance killed.  The only family member of either house to survive was a young son of House Hollard.  Ser Barristan begged for his life and because Aerys owed him a debt for rescuing him from the dungeon, he granted the boon.  

Ser Barristan took the boy back to Kings Landing with him as his squire.  This lad was of course Dontos Hollard who grew up to be Sansa Stark’s symbolic Florian.  A sad and poor version of the legendary knight was Dontos.   He was only in it for the money but he did help her escape from Kings Landing and did teach her some valuable lessons about the game of thrones.  With Dontos, Sansa’s pretend Florian being from Duskendale; we see again how heavily her arc is tied up with the past events from that area as well as Maidenpool region.

The color of Dontos hair is never given in the text but an interesting detail about him that is not often mentioned is that he is also called “Dontos the Red.”  Why he has this moniker is never stated.  It may have something to do with his alcoholism and him possibly always being red of face.  However, with the preponderance of redheads from the Duskendale area, more than likely the moniker pertains to his hair color.  This is especially true as Dontos; the Red makes one immediately think of the famous Viking, Erik, the Red who was so named because of his red hair and beard.

Kiss by fire redheads are part of a very important and mysterious theme in the books.  If Dontos is a redhead as I speculate, then here we have another scarlet hair individual from Duskendale.  This is quite a lot of references to redheaded individuals from an area that ostensibly have nothing to do with the central story.  And yet, the tale of Duskendale and past events that happened there are referenced in all the books except for A Game of Thrones.  This includes the ancillary Dunk and Egg novellas.  Why?  

Why does it play such a major role in the arc of Sansa Stark?  She has actually never visited Duskendale as she went directly to the Vale after escaping from Kings Landing.  However, if she had traveled by land, she most likely would have travel through Duskendale on the way to the Vale.  But that was not her escape route.  Instead, she went by ship and so sailed directly to the Fingers.  Nonetheless, she is still strongly associated with the area as Dontos is from the region and it is where Brienne went in search of him and the missing Sansa.

Florian of course first saw Jonquil at Maidenpool, which as I’ve previously noted, borders Duskendale.  @RoseOfRedLake has a wonderful essay about the importance of Maidenpool and the role it has played in the story so far and potentially may in the future.   Maybe it’s because Duskendale neighbors Maidenpool that it is featured so prominently in the books.  That could be part of the reason but maybe there is more to it.

I wondered earlier whether Jonquil was from Maidenpool or if she was just visiting the pool on her way to another location.  As luck would have it, George has provided several hints in Fire and Blood that it may be the second option.

While on a royal progress with Jaehaerys, Alysanne decided to visit Jonquil’s healing pool for a bath.  One interesting aspect of her visit is the fact prior to arriving in Maidenpool the couple visited Duskendale.

They began with Stokeworth and Rosby, then moved north along the coast to Duskendale.  There, whilst the king viewed Lord Darklyn’s boatyards and enjoyed an afternoon of fishing, the queen held the first of her women’s courts, which were to become an important part of every royal progress to come. Only women and girls were welcome at these audiences; highborn or low, they were encouraged to come forward and share their fears, concerns, and hopes with the young queen.

The journey went without incident until the king and queen reached Maidenpool, where they were to be the guests of Lord and Lady Mooton for a fortnight before sailing across the Bay of Crabs to Wickenden, Gulltown, and the Vale.

Fire and Blood: Birth, Death and Betrayal under King Jaehaerys 1

Before arriving in Maidenpool, the royal progress may have stopped at Antlers or Rook’s Rest.  However, they could have travel directly from Duskendale to Maidenpool without a stop in-between.  As they were traveling along the coast, it would have been more likely that they stopped at Rook’s Rest as opposed to Antlers but as it was a progress, they most likely stopped in both areas.  

However, unlike with the mention of Stokeworth and Rosby, George makes no mention of these other two towns.  The text goes straight from Jaehaerys and Alysanne being in Duskendale to them in Maidenpool.  It’s almost as if George wants you to associate the two towns with each other.  This is something he does on numerous occasions throughout the various books as the towns are often grouped together…almost as a unit.  

I proposed that the reason for this is because Jonquil in point of fact was not from Maidenpool as many assume.  Maidenpool is the location of the famous pool where Florian first saw Jonquil but nowhere does it say that it was the location of her birth.  Instead, I believe Florian first saw her there simply because like Alysanne, her and her party stop there to rest and refresh themselves in the local pool.  I think that it’s possible that she was either from Duskendale or had family who resided there that she was visiting.  

As Jonquil was familiar with Florian’s name, he might have been from the region as well.  And I think that this could be why Duskendale and Maidenpool are always linked in the text.

This morning the puppeteers were doing the tale of Florian and Jonquil. The fat Dornishwoman was working Florian in his armor made of motley, while the tall girl held Jonquil’s strings. “You are no knight,” she was saying as the puppet’s mouth moved up and down. “I know you. You are Florian the Fool.”

“I am, my lady,” the other puppet answered, kneeling. “As great a fool as ever lived, and as great a knight as well.”

The Hedge Knight

I mentioned that Jonquil might possibly have been from Duskendale or had family in the region.  However, there is one other area from which she might have been born. There are many hints in Fire & Blood that suggest that Alysanne’s story offer clues to that of Sansa.  And I think that one of the ways it does this is with the story of Florian and Jonquil.  

Jaehaerys and Alysanne arrived in Maidenpool from Duskendale only for the queen to be attacked when she visited Jonquil’s pool.

The goodness of the little queen, the silence of the Starry Sept, and the exhortations of the Seven Speakers had won over most of the Faithful for Jaehaerys and his Alysanne…but there are always some who will not be moved, and amongst the sisters who tended Jonquil’s Pool were three such women, whose hearts were hard with hate. They told one another that their holy waters would be polluted forever were the queen allowed to bathe in them whilst carrying the king’s “abomination” in her belly. Queen Alysanne had only slipped out of her clothing when they fell upon her with daggers they had concealed within their robes.

Fire and Blood: Birth, Death and Betrayal Under King Jaehaerys I

Her ladies-in-waiting foiled the attempt on Alysanne and the two Kings Guards assigned to her.  However, it also forced her and Jaehaerys to end their progress and return to Kings Landing.

A raven flew to Duskendale that very night, commanding the new Lord Darklyn to send to court his bastard half-sister, Jonquil Darke, who had thrilled the smallfolk during the War for the White Cloaks as the mystery knight known as the Serpent in Scarlet. Still in scarlet, she arrived at King’s Landing a few days later, and gladly accepted appointment as the queen’s own sworn shield. In time, she would be known about the realm as the Scarlet Shadow, so closely did she guard her lady.

Fire and Blood: Birth, Death and Betrayal Under King Jaehaerys I

So we have Alysanne who Martin has written to parallel Sansa in so many ways arriving at Maidenpool from Duskendale.  Then after visiting Jonquil’s pool where she is attacked, she sends to Duskendale for her own personal female guard.  One that just happens to be named Jonquil and quite possibly may have been a redhead

Also, let’s not forget that Brienne goes searching for Sansa, the in-story symbolic stand-in for Jonquil in Duskendale.  When she has no luck there she heads over to Maidenpool where Lord Tarly is now in control.

"If the Stark girl were here, I’d know it. She’s run back north, I’ll wager. Hoping to find refuge with one of her father’s bannermen. She had best hope she chooses the right one.”

“She might have gone to the Vale instead,” Brienne heard herself blurt out, “to her mother’s sister.”

Lord Randyll gave her a contemptuous look. “Lady Lysa is dead. Some singer pushed her off a mountain. Littlefinger holds the Eyrie now … though not for long. The lords of the Vale are not the sort to bend their knees to some upjumped jackanapes whose only skill is counting coppers.”

A Feast for Crows - Brienne III

Brienne should have trusted her instincts because Sansa is of course in the Vale.  The interesting thing about the Vale is that it was the planned final destination of the royal progress and it was the next stop after Maidenpool.  The attack on Alysanne’s forced the King and Queen returned to Kings Landing, making plans to visit the Vale at a future date.  As I mentioned previously, if Sansa had travelled to the Vale overland instead of via water, she would have followed the same path as Alysanne and Jaehaerys.

With all these symbolic Jonquils connected to or traveling from Duskendale to Maidenpool to the Vale, is it possible that the original followed the same path?  Is it possible that she was from Duskendale and she only stopped in Maidenpool on the way to her final destination in the Vale?  Or is the reverse true and she was traveling from the Vale to Duskendale and only stopped in Maidenpool to rest.  With Sansa’s symbolic connection to all three areas, I believe that one of these options is true and it is what George wants us to consider.  And if we can figure out which one is correct, we may be one step closer to answering the great mystery of the series.

We have reviewed the many clues that suggest that Jonquil was a “kissed by fire” redhead and briefly looked at hints that she was also short in stature.  All of the females that I mentioned who tip to Jonquil having red hair were described as short or at least it was intimated that they were.  Let’s now look at one other scene with Dunk, the Florian that supports my thesis that she was short.  It’s a memory that occurs to Dunk just after he speaks to Tanselle, the Jonquil surrogate for the first time.

“Will you drink a horn of ale?” he asked the puppet girl as she was scooping the sawdust blood back into her dragon. “With me, I mean? Or a sausage? I had a sausage last night, and it was good. They’re made with pork, I think.”

“I thank you, m'lord, but we have another show.” The girl rose, and ran off to the fierce fat Dornishwoman who worked the puppet knight while Dunk stood there feeling stupid. He liked the way she ran, though. A pretty girl, and tall. I would not have to kneel to kiss that one. He knew how to kiss.

A tavern girl had showed him one night in Lannisport, a year ago, but she’d been so short she had to sit on the table to reach his lips. The memory made his ears burn. What a great fool he was. It was jousting he should be thinking about, not kissing.

The Hedge Knight

Why did Martin make the girl of Dunk’s memory so short in height if it was not to hint at something?  As the memory of her comes to him just after he has seen the puppet show about Florian and Jonquil and his brief conversation with Tanselle, it’s quite possible that it’s a clue to Jonquil’s height.  At the same time, Martin also has Dunk mentally call himself a fool so that we the reader can link him to Florian and a short female.  

The fact that George keeps hinting at her being short in stature must mean that it is of some importance to the story.  I think that Jonquil’s height is in fact of extreme consequence, as we will discover a bit later in the essay series.

One final point I want to mention about Dunk’s brief conversation with Tanselle is his invitation for her to go and have a horn of ale and a pork sausage with him.  Dunk is an innocent but we the readers know that horns and sausages…especially the pork kind comes with all sorts of sexual innuendos.  And so we see again how the fertility theme is constantly running through the Florian and Jonquil arc.  

This brings us to the end of part 3.  In the next chapter, sausages come into play again as we look at a curious textural error in The Hedge Knight and ponder whether it was a mistake or if it was a deliberate on Martin’s part.  And we also take a look at Mary Magdalene because if they are suggestions of a symbolic Christ in the story one would expect some hints of Mary Magdalene as well. It turns out that there quite possibly are such clues and in a most surprising way.

You may read the other chapters of this essay at the following links.

Part 2

Part 4
